etymologies: early 17th century: from French défroquer, from dé- (expressing removal) + froc ‘frock’

definitions: deprive (a person in holy orders) of ecclesiastical status

examples.text: he had left his diocese one step ahead of a move to defrock him

shortDefinitions: deprive person in holy orders of ecclesiastical status

definitions: deprive (someone) of professional status or membership of a prestigious group

examples.text: the Supreme Court found him in contempt of the tribunal and defrocked him as an appeals court judge

shortDefinitions: deprive someone of professional status or membership of prestigious group
